articles.headline: Japan Re-Emerges in the Aerospace Arena With a New Jet
articles.snippet: In World War II, the country produced the feared Mitsubishi Zero fighter planes. Today, the same company is working on a regional jet that it hopes will propel it into the industry’s big leagues.
articles.abstract: In World War II, the country produced the feared Mitsubishi Zero fighter planes. Today, the same company is working on a regional jet that it hopes will propel it into the industry’s big leagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As a small boy, Teruaki Kawai watched wide-eyed as American DC-3s took off and landed at a small airport across an inlet from his home on the Hiroshima coast.

articles.headline: Lew’s Visit to Europe Reveals a Wide Policy Divide
articles.snippet: The two-day effort by the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to persuade Europe to reconsider its commitment to austerity met with courteous but firm rejection.
articles.abstract: The two-day effort by the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to persuade Europe to reconsider its commitment to austerity met with courteous but firm rejection.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The two-day effort by the United States Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to persuade Europe to consider shifting its focus from budget balance to growth highlighted a deep trans-Atlantic policy gulf that is likely to leave Europe as a drag on the global economy.

articles.headline: Threat to Block Debate on Guns Appears to Fade in Senate
articles.snippet: Several Senate Republicans said they would not join in any filibuster of the first major gun control bill since 1993, and Senator Harry Reid said he would set an initial showdown vote.
articles.abstract: Several Senate Republicans said they would not join in any filibuster of the first major gun control bill since 1993, and Senator Harry Reid said he would set an initial showdown vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would not participate in a filibuster of the first major gun control bill since 1993, as Democrats appeared on the verge of overcoming a blockade threatened by a group of conservatives before a word of debate on the measure was uttered.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: From Mexico, Some Lessons for Europe
articles.snippet: Like Europe today, Mexico three decades ago tried deep budget cuts and other measures to deal with debt, but a U-turn by creditors finally turned the tide.
articles.abstract: Like Europe today, Mexico three decades ago tried deep budget cuts and other measures to deal with debt, but a U-turn by creditors finally turned the tide.
articles.lead_paragraph: I was in Mexico City in the summer of 1981, just out of high school, when Mexico’s president, José López Portillo, announced he would defend the peso “like a dog” against speculative attacks.

articles.headline: Broadcasters Circle Wagons Against a TV Streaming Upstart
articles.snippet: Aereo denies stations the fees cable operators pay to retransmit their signals, so networks are determined to shut it down — even, they say, if they have to go cable-only.
articles.abstract: Aereo denies stations the fees cable operators pay to retransmit their signals, so networks are determined to shut it down — even, they say, if they have to go cable-only.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Chase Carey, Rupert Murdoch’s top deputy at News Corporation, told broadcasters on Monday about his contingency plan to turn the Fox network into something available only on cable, he knew policy makers would be listening, too. But a few of them were busy that day, meeting with Chet Kanojia, the very man who had provoked Mr. Carey’s stark warning.

articles.headline: Peace Envoys From Taliban at Loose Ends in Qatar
articles.snippet: After peace talks with the United States broke down in Doha, eight or more relatively high-ranking Taliban officials remained there without a mission.
articles.abstract: After peace talks with the United States broke down in Doha, eight or more relatively high-ranking Taliban officials remained there without a mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — When a handful of Taliban emissaries flew into Qatar on an American plane in 2010, the Obama administration hoped they would help negotiate a peace deal that could stabilize Afghanistan and allow the United States a graceful exit.

articles.headline: Chief’s Silicon Valley Stardom Quickly Clashed at J.C. Penney
articles.snippet: In his 17 months trying to remake the chain, Ronald B. Johnson relied on his instincts and rebuffed the doubts of others, associates say.
articles.abstract: In his 17 months trying to remake the chain, Ronald B. Johnson relied on his instincts and rebuffed the doubts of others, associates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the ice sculptures. Or the order to stock slim, European-style men’s suits. Or the swagger of a protégé of the mighty Steve Jobs.

articles.headline: A Solution for Penney May Be to Sell Itself, or Some of Its Assets
articles.snippet: With Ron Johnson’s ouster this week, J.C. Penney, a 111-year-old retail chain, is scrambling to ensure that it has a future at all. And the solution may be a sale of some or all of the company.
articles.abstract: With Ron Johnson’s ouster this week, J.C. Penney, a 111-year-old retail chain, is scrambling to ensure that it has a future at all. And the solution may be a sale of some or all of the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, William A. Ackman, a newly minted board member of J. C. Penney, quietly met with the man he hoped would lead the struggling retailer to a brighter future.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Obama Pushes His Choice for Position on Appeals Court
articles.snippet: A lobbying effort to install Sri Srinivasan on the most prestigious appellate court will test a strategy that the White House hopes will put Republicans in a bind.
articles.abstract: A lobbying effort to install Sri Srinivasan on the most prestigious appellate court will test a strategy that the White House hopes will put Republicans in a bind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a coordination and an energy that echo a Supreme Court nomination fight, the Obama administration is pushing for the confirmation of a senior Justice Department lawyer to the country’s most prestigious appellate court. If the effort fails, it could lead to a confrontation with the Senate over the long-simmering issue of judicial nominees.

articles.headline: Former Regulators Find a Home With a Powerful Firm
articles.snippet: Promontory Financial is a consulting firm stocked with former government officials and paid billions by banks to help them navigate an onslaught of new regulations.
articles.abstract: Promontory Financial is a consulting firm stocked with former government officials and paid billions by banks to help them navigate an onslaught of new regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The consulting firm is filled with so many former bureaucrats and political insiders that it has become known as Wall Street’s shadow regulator.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Facebook Grabs for Your Phone. What Gives?
articles.snippet: With a set of apps for Android phones, Facebook is commandeering the home page. And the ads are coming soon.
articles.abstract: With a set of apps for Android phones, Facebook is commandeering the home page. And the ads are coming soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook, man. Unbelievable. Second-most-visited Web site in the world. Frequented monthly by one-sixth of the earth’s population. Primary source of news for half of America’s young people.

articles.headline: Obama Budget Opens Rift for Democrats on Social Benefits
articles.snippet: President Obama’s gamble in making concessions to Republicans on Medicare and Social Security drew anger from those to his left. But others in his party see such changes as necessary.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s gamble in making concessions to Republicans on Medicare and Social Security drew anger from those to his left. But others in his party see such changes as necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s new budget has opened a debate over what it means to be a progressive Democrat in an age of austerity and defines him as a president willing to take on the two pillars of his party — Medicare and Social Security — created by Democratic presidents.

articles.headline: A Senator’s Search for an Ally Keeps a Gun Bill Alive
articles.snippet: Two of the National Rifle Association’s favorites in the Senate came together in a last-ditch effort on a background check deal that opened the door for Congress to consider new gun laws.
articles.abstract: Two of the National Rifle Association’s favorites in the Senate came together in a last-ditch effort on a background check deal that opened the door for Congress to consider new gun laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III so craved a pro-gun-rights Republican as a partner for a bill to expand background checks on gun buyers that he took to buttonholing senators on the in-house subway that ferries them from their offices to the Capitol, making his pitch while his colleagues were trapped with him in the tiny car.

articles.headline: By Accident, Fed Gives Early Data to Banks
articles.snippet: Officials insisted that no traders benefited from the accidental distribution of minutes from their March meeting, which were sent to a virtual Who’s Who of Wall Street firms.
articles.abstract: Officials insisted that no traders benefited from the accidental distribution of minutes from their March meeting, which were sent to a virtual Who’s Who of Wall Street firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve alerted bank officials on Tuesday that policy makers were considering a shift on when to begin easing back on stimulus efforts, a day before the news was released publicly, but it insisted there was no evidence traders on Wall Street had benefited from what was called an error.
